        <p class="date">
         Wed Sep 03, 2008 at 08:10 AM PDT
        </p>
        <h2>
         <a href="/story/2008/09/03/584551/-Biden-Criminal-charges-against-Bush-Admin-on-the-table" id="titleHref">
          Biden: Criminal charges against Bush Admin. on the table
         </a>
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
         </span>
        </h2>
        <p class="author">
         <span>
          by
         </span>
         <a href="/user/Devin">
          Devin
         </a>
         <a alt="Follow this author" class="ajax type-user do-hotlist do-updateContent size-tiny off altTooltip" href="#?friend_id=112&amp;is_stream=1">
          Follow
         </a>
        </p>
        <ul class="front-page-share clearfix">
         <li style="margin-left: 0px">
          <div class="fb-share-button" data-href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2008/09/03/584551/-Biden-Criminal-charges-against-Bush-Admin-on-the-table" data-layout="button_count">
          </div>
         </li>
         <li>
          <a class="twitter-share-button" data-count="horizontal" data-related="markos" data-text="Biden: Criminal charges against Bush Admin. on the table" data-url="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2008/09/03/584551/-Biden-Criminal-charges-against-Bush-Admin-on-the-table" data-via="dailykos" href="https://twitter.com/share">
           Tweet
          </a>
         </li>
         <li>
          <a class="comments comment_count_with_new" data-comment_count="479" data-story_id="584551" href="/story/2008/09/03/584551/-Biden-Criminal-charges-against-Bush-Admin-on-the-table#comments">
           479 Comments
          </a>
         </li>
        </ul>
       </div>
       <div class="article-body">
        <div id="intro">
         <p>
          Holy crap. Boy howdy, did Political Radar
          <a href="http://blogs.abcnews.com/politicalradar/2008/09/biden-rips-bush.html">
           bury the lede
          </a>
          in a big way. I direct your attention to the 9th and 10th paragraphs of their blog post about Biden ripping into Bush today:
         </p>
         <blockquote>
          <p>
           Looking to the future but with one eye on the past, Biden also promised that an Obama-Biden government would go through Bush administration data with "a fine-toothed comb" and pursue criminal charges if necessary.
          </p>
          <p>
           "If there has been a basis upon which you can pursue someone for a criminal violation," he said, "they will be pursued, not out of vengeance, not out of retribution - out of the need to preserve the notion that no one, no one, no attorney general, no president, no one is above the law."
          </p>
         </blockquote>
         <p>
          The man who is very likely going to be the next Vice-President of this country just said that they are going to undertake a detailed review of the last eight years of Bush Administration conduct and pursue criminal charges where they are warranted.
         </p>
         <p>
          Wow. Just....wow.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Update:
          </strong>
          Thanks for the recs, guys. Maybe someone in the MSM will see it there and decide that it needs to be in the first paragraph instead of the 9th.
         </p>
        </div>
        <p class="divider-doodle">
        </p>
        <div class="article-body" id="body">
         <p>
          <strong>
           Update #2:
          </strong>
          As pointed out in the comments, Obama himself
          <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/04/15/obama-would-immediately-r_n_96690.html">
           has said something similar
          </a>
          recently. I must have missed that when it first appeared. But I would like to point out that Biden's statement is much more aggressive than Obama's, and that in itself is noteworthy.
         </p>
         <p>
          <strong>
           Update #3:
          </strong>
          At the risk of sounding like a giggly fanboy, I have to say that for me, it is the height of coolness to be on the rec list right next to
          <strong>
           Michael Moore
          </strong>
          , of all people. And quite appropriate as well, since Moore has been hollering about BushCo's criminal conduct for quite some time now.
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
       <h4>
        Originally posted to
        <a href="/blog/Devin/">
         Devin
        </a>
        on Wed Sep 03, 2008 at 08:10 AM PDT.
       </h4>

        <div>
         <p>
          Add keywords that describe this diary.
		Separate multiple keywords with commas.
          <br/>
          <a href="/special/tag_tips" target="_blank">
           Tagging tips
          </a>
          -
          <a href="/search?search_tags=1" target="_blank">
           Search For Tags
          </a>
          -
          <a href="http://www.dkosopedia.com/wiki/Tag:Tagfinder" target="_blank">
           Browse For Tags
          </a>
         </p>
         <div class="pageTip hasTooltip" style="margin-top:3px">
          ?
         </div>
         <div class="tooltipContents qtip-style-dk4_large qtip-pos-br">
          <p>
           <b>
            More Tagging tips:
           </b>
          </p>
          <p>
           A tag is a way to search for this diary. If someone is searching for "Barack Obama," is this a diary they'd be trying to find?
          </p>
          <p>
           Use a person's full name, without any title. Senator Obama may become President Obama, and Michelle Obama might run for office.
          </p>
          <p>
           If your diary covers an election or elected official, use election tags, which are generally the state abbreviation followed by the office. 
		CA-01 is the first district House seat. CA-Sen covers both senate races. NY-GOV covers the New York governor's race.
          </p>
          <p>
           Tags do not compound: that is, "education reform" is a completely different tag from "education". A tag like "reform" alone is probably not meaningful.
          </p>
         </div>
         <!-- &lt;h4 id="p_tagErrorMessage"&gt;You must enter at least one Tag for this Diary Entry:&lt;/h4&gt; -->

          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Education');return false;">
           Education
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Elections');return false;">
           Elections
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Energy');return false;">
           Energy
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Environment');return false;">
           Environment
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Health Care');return false;">
           Health Care
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('International');return false;">
           International
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Labor');return false;">
           Labor
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Law');return false;">
           Law
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Media');return false;">
           Media
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Meta');return false;">
           Meta
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('National Security');return false;">
           National Security
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Science');return false;">
           Science
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Transportation');return false;">
           Transportation
          </a>
          , or
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('White House');return false;">
           White House
          </a>
          .
	If your diary is specific to a state, consider adding the state 
	(
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('California');return false;">
           California
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="#" onclick="addTagToField('Texas');return false;">
           Texas
          </a>
          , etc).
	Keep in mind, though, that there are many wonderful and important diaries
	that don't fit in any of these tags. Don't worry if yours doesn't.
         </p>
        </div>
       </form>
      </div>

           <p>
            ...to God's ears. Please, finally, let there be some accountability for this criminal racket called the Bush Administration.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
            <i>
             <a href="http://www.architecturaldigest.com/homes/features/archive/mccain_article_072005" rel="nofollow">

             </a>
             of John McCain's 10 houses is the nicest?

               <p>
                are (the 28%) counting on blanket pardons.
               </p>
               <p>
                I think there should be a real Truth and Reconciliation commission though...so at least the history books are right and they assert that our government
               </p>
               <ol>
                <li value="1">
                 started a war for oil, that killed a million
                </li>
               </ol>
               <ol>
                <li value="2">
                 required its agents to torture prisoners
                </li>
               </ol>
               <ol>
                <li value="3">
                 allowed a criminal terrorist to get away for 7 years
                </li>
               </ol>
               <ol>
                <li value="4">
                 played politics with the DOJ
                </li>
               </ol>
               <ol>
                <li value="5">
                 improsened without charges hundreds of people
                </li>
               </ol>
               <ol>
                <li value="6">
                 spied on its own peoiple wihtout cause or process
                </li>
               </ol>
               <ol>
                <li value="7">
                 oh forget it, this list will go on for a real long time, i'll give up here...this is a job for the T&amp;R commision.
                </li>
               </ol>
               <p>
                anyone who doesn't show up to the commission, or is shown to lie, should be given real felonies. Cooperative witnesses should be granted immunity.
               </p>

                     </a>

                   <div class="ct">
                    <p>
                     and torture are special cases. They are called "jus cogens" and are not pardonable. They also have no statute of limitations and are prosecutable from any jurisdiction. IANAL, but these facts were presented as Congressional testimony by a Constitutional Law professor a few months ago.

                     <div class="ct">
                      <p>
                       At least not until after the inauguration.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       If the brownshirts who have been ruling over this nation for the past decade think there's really a chance that they might be held accountable for what they've done, then the elections will either be canceled or stolen, or there will be tanks and troops in the streets.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       You think these people are going to wait politely to be frog-marched off to the war crimes trials? You forget who we're dealing with here.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       I hope there's a thorough examination of what's been done. But we shouldn't be talking about that just yet. We've still got an election to win, and a new administration to take power. There are still too many ways that could be thwarted.
                      </p>

                       treason
                      </em>
                      for giving aid and comfort to the enemy. We know that the Bush family has close ties to the Saudi royals, and we also know that the Saudi royals have close ties to Bin Ladin and Al Qeda. We can fill in the blanks with a few confessions by way of
                      <em>
                       Enhanced Interrogation
                      </em>
                      . The kicker is that international War Crimes tribunals can only sentence perps to life, but they'll get
                      <em>
                       death
                      </em>
                      for treason. Fair is fair.
                     </p>
                    </div>

            <li id="c245">

               <a class="de">

               </span>

               </p>
               <p>
                My ideal scenario would be to keep the issue quiet for now, then once Obama is elected to move full steam ahead on the prosecutions. Perhaps this is too much to hope for.

                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Obama said this over a year ago at Yearly Kos
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/584551/22080026#c250?mode=alone;showrate=1#c250">
                   12+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:25169">
                    ivote2004
                   </a>

                   <a href="/user/uid:25329">

                   </a>

                    violenza
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  Here's the video. Comes about six minutes in:
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <object height="344" width="425">
                   <param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/KdzcSkMCd54&amp;hl=en&amp;fs=1">
                   </param>
                   <param name="allowFullScreen" value="true">
                   </param>
                   <embed allowfullscreen="true" height="344" src="http://www.youtube.com/v/KdzcSkMCd54&amp;hl=en&amp;fs=1" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="425">
                   </embed>
                  </object>
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  He doesn't use the word "criminal," but he does say that he's going to get his
                  <strong>
                   Attorney General
                  </strong>
                  to do a thorough review of every action the Bush administration has taken.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Seems to me that if he's going to use his AG, he's looking for crimes.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  He also says that this will be his second priority, after Iraq. That leaves me with the impression that he thinks this is as important as we do.
                 </p>
                </div>

             <ul class="cm i1" id="k22078376">
              <li id="c266">
               <div class="cx" id="cx22080464">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Top Priority
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/584551/22080464#c266?mode=alone;showrate=1#c266">
                   2+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:52760">
                    llywrch
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:109379">
                    kafkananda
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  First let me state I am a conservative, not a Republican, but a conservative. I read opinions from across the political spectrum to be informed. So, yes I troll these sites, but only to be informed.
                 </p>
                 <blockquote>
                  <p>
                   The top priority.
                   <br/>
                   There need to be full investigations, then indictments, prosecutions, conviction, and imprisonment.
                  </p>
                 </blockquote>
                 <p>
                  How can you say an investigation of Bush is the top priority when we are:
                 </p>
                 <ol>
                  <li value="1">
                   At war (I'm an anti-war conservative)
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <ol>
                  <li value="2">
                   Skirting a recession
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <ol>
                  <li value="3">
                   Healthcare in disarray
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <ol>
                  <li value="4">
                   Spending out of control
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <ol>
                  <li value="5">
                   A massive debt accumulating for our children (Social Security and Medicare)
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <ol>
                  <li value="6">
                   Masssive failure in secondary education shown by the high drop-out rates.
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <ol>
                  <li value="7">
                   Potential attack in Iran, we have three carriers in the area and sailors and marines are being sent to the gulf fleet (this part is second hand knowledge)
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <ol>
                  <li value="8">
                   The only approval rating lower than Bush's is that of the Congress (there's a powerful message for us all)
                  </li>
                 </ol>
                 <p>
                  It would seem that your distain for the right over-rides the critical issues facing us today.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Further, how can you say there should be investigations, then indictments, prosecutions, conviction, and imprisonment. The country I want to live in would conduct an investigation, then decide if the other stuff is necessary, one step at a time.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Would that we could engage in a civil discussion without personalizing disagreements. My views are my views only, not an attack on others' views. I'm Buddhist, that doesn mean I have distain or dislike of Christians, Jews, Muslims, or Hindus. As a Buddhist, I don't believe in a Supreme Being so I guess that makes me a conservative atheist, does that mean of a right-wing liberal wacko? :-)
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  "Compassion and tolerance are not signs of weakness, indeed they are signs of strength." - His Holiness, the Dalai Lama

                   <blockquote>
                    <p>
                     No one wants Bush criminals imprisoned without trial, we just want to make sure that they actually are tried in a court of law, then if found guilty, imprisoned, just like they want to do to people who are found with drugs, for example. No "special" privileges here.
                    </p>
                   </blockquote>
                   <p>
                    You're probably right in the main. Perhaps
                    <em>
                     <strong>
                      America
                     </strong>
                    </em>
                    worded it badly. I agree with you, he is no different from anyone else and should be accorded the same rights as the rest of us.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    But you too say Bush criminals. I'm prepared to believe this, and support investigations, but I'm not prepared to say it is so or agree with it until a trial has been conducted. Because I don't like what he's done, doesn't make him a criminal. I don't have first hand knowledge of his discussions with the Congress, the validity of the intelligence (shoot, even Sadam's generals thought he had WMD, big surprise for them I betcha!). We've released enough innocent folks for death row for me to be very mindful quick accusations.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">

                   <h5>
                    <a class="de">
                    </a>
                    <span class="cu">
                     Re
                    </span>
                    <span class="crd ntb">
                     (
                     <a href="/comments/584551/22082751#c317?mode=alone;showrate=1#c317">

                   <div class="crs">
                    <dl>
                     <dt>
                      Recommended by:
                     </dt>
                     <dd>
                      <a href="/user/uid:3312">

                       James Kresnik
                      </a>
                     </dd>
                    </dl>
                   </div>
                   <div class="ct">
                    <p>
                     Thanks for the discussion.
                    </p>
                    <blockquote>
                     <p>
                      But you too say Bush criminals. I'm prepared to believe this, and support investigations, but I'm not prepared to say it is so or agree with it until a trial has been conducted.
                     </p>
                    </blockquote>
                    <p>
                     I am convinced that there is adequate evidence of criminal behavior by various people inside Bushco to warrant calling them "criminals". While a criminal court will require evidence beyond a reasonable doubt for conviction and punishment, I merely hold myself in my use of language to the "preponderance of evidence" standard and here there is plenty of evidence of a wide variety of crimes.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     You and I can disagree on this without any kind of unpleasantness. As long as you support investigations, then whether you are correct or I am will come out in the wash in any case and due process will be properly served.
                    </p>
                    <blockquote>
                     <p>
                      Because I don't like what he's done, doesn't make him a criminal. I don't have first hand knowledge of his discussions with the Congress, the validity of the intelligence (shoot, even Sadam's generals thought he had WMD, big surprise for them I betcha!). We've released enough innocent folks for death row for me to be very mindful quick accusations.
                     </p>
                    </blockquote>
                    <p>
                     While I admire your willingness to withhold judgement on people, I assure you my calling them "criminals" was based on my own opinion backed up by (in my view) substantial evidence in all the areas you point out above.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     I will also point out also that whether the intelligence was correct or not may not have a bearing on the matter here. If Bush used WMD to justify a war to Congress that he
                     <strong>
                      really
                     </strong>
                     wanted for
                     <strong>
                      other
                     </strong>
                     reasons, then
                     <strong>
                      that
                     </strong>
                     is a felony and a war crime on its own.
                    </p>
                    <p>
                     I do not believe that my position should be enough to convince a court of law of someone's guilt, but it
                     <strong>
                      is
                     </strong>
                     enough that I can call them criminals with a clean conscience.
                    </p>
                   </div>

                    <p class="sig">
                     <a href="http://www.politicalcompass.org" rel="nofollow">

                 <div class="cf">
                  <p class="sig">
                   Obama/O'Biden/08 - Our American Prayer
                  </p>
                  <p class="cb">
                   by
                   <a href="/user/uid:133665">

               <ul class="cm i1" id="k22081363">
                <li id="c299">
                 <div class="cx" id="cx22081838">
                  <h5>
                   <a class="de">
                   </a>
                   <span class="cu">
                    Mercy
                   </span>
                   <span class="crd ntb">
                    (
                    <a href="/comments/584551/22081838#c299?mode=alone;showrate=1#c299">
                     0+ / 0-
                    </a>
                    )
                   </span>
                  </h5>
                  <div class="ct">
                   <p>
                    Grandma, there is enough blame to go around. There were hundreds of school busses under water, there remain thousands of unused emergency mobile homes still sitting around, there was a failure of city leadership to promptly call for an evacuation and, as required by law, to ask for federal help.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    That said, Homeland Security should have acted quickly overriding city leadership (now that would have been a circus!). Bush clearly should have exerted the pressure of the White House to get things moving.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    The New Orleans disaster has less to do with politics and more to do with leadership.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Could you cite specifics on Bush's war-profiteering and Justice Department manipulations? Thanks.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="cf">
                   <p class="sig">

                       </p>

                      <p>
                       Allegations are just that. Her allegations regarding nuclear black markets related to Hastert, not the Executive Branch. She alleged he accepted bribes to sell nuclear secrets to Turkey and Pakistan which were sold onward to North Korea.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       Where he hid the money, I don't know. Ms. Edmunds was a Turkish translator, while not dismissing her allegations out of hand, she seems very knowledgeable regarding stuff well outside her baliwick.
                      </p>
                      <p>
                       We seem so quick to label folks as criminals based solely on allegations. This is a very facist way of acting. Surely we should expect better of ourselves.

                       <p>
                        Sure I do, you just don't have to agree with me, we just should try to be civil about it with each other. As to investigation, there is settled case law on this. If there is cause, there can be an investigation. It's really that simple.
                       </p>
                       <blockquote>
                        <p>

                        </p>

                       <p>
                        I'm not sure where I've defended the accused or from what, I'm just from the school that the courts decide guilt or innocence. It's facists and their ilk who allow inuendo and rumour to determine guilt. Regardless of how credible rumours are, we all deserve our day in court I should think.
                       </p>
                       <blockquote>
                        <p>
                         Who needs pardons when you can go to Congress!
                        </p>
                       </blockquote>
                       <p>
                        If Bush was able to convince the Houses of Congress to approve the law, then who is to blame? Surely we can agree on this.
                       </p>
                       <blockquote>
                        <p>
                         Keep on believing, dude. Whatever gets them another day to put your taxes in Dubai
                        </p>
                       </blockquote>
                       <p>
                        How much of our taxes are going to Dubai and for what reason? This is actually new news to me.
                       </p>

            <li id="c184">
             <div class="cx" id="cx22077857">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Sunstein is a joker. He has some good scholarship
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/584551/22077857#c184?mode=alone;showrate=1#c184">
                 2+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:27118">
                  wonmug
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:45698">
                  3goldens
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                to his name, but then he also wrote a book called
                <em>
                 Republic.com 2.0
                </em>
                claiming that polarization of political discourse on the internet is a threat to democracy. Sunstein is a big-time get off my lawn-er, and while I'm sure he made valuable contributions to Obama's intellectual development and to scholarship, he's not somebody whose comments I would take too seriously.
               </p>
              </div>

            <li id="c125">
             <div class="cx" id="cx22076726">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Cass Sunstein
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/584551/22076726#c125?mode=alone;showrate=1#c125">
                 8+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:17368">
                  dnamj
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:27118">
                  wonmug
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:75268">
                  Pager
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:75333">
                  joe shikspack
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:81370">
                  Mary2002
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:92045">
                  ColoTim
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:126241">
                  James Kresnik
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:174871">
                  bicycle Hussein paladin
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <blockquote>
                <p>
                 Writing from the Netroots Nation conference, The Nation's Ari Melber detailed what he calls "Bipartisan Attacks on the Rule of Law," and specifically highlighted the fact that close Obama adviser, Professor Cass Sunstein of the University of Chicago, "cautioned against prosecuting criminal conduct from the current Administration" during a Conference panel. As Melber wrote:
                </p>
                <blockquote>
                 <p>
                  Prosecuting government officials risks a "cycle" of criminalizing public service, [Sunstein] argued, and Democrats should avoid replicating retributive efforts like the impeachment of President Clinton -- or even the "slight appearance" of it
                 </p>
                </blockquote>
                <p>
                 .
                </p>
               </blockquote>
              </div>

                 Any action against the current administration needs to be seen as fair and non-partisan as possible.
                </p>
                <p>
                 If Bush's people are prosecuted in a manner that can be portrayed as a political move on the part of Democrats then we'll have to fight an unnecessary "payback" battle in the future.

             <ul class="cm i1" id="k22081373">
              <li id="c357">
               <div class="cx" id="cx22085638">
                <h5>
                 <a class="de">
                 </a>
                 <span class="cu">
                  Well, there is some right in both views.
                 </span>
                 <span class="crd ntb">
                  (
                  <a href="/comments/584551/22085638#c357?mode=alone;showrate=1#c357">
                   3+ / 0-
                  </a>
                  )
                 </span>
                </h5>
                <div class="crs">
                 <dl>
                  <dt>
                   Recommended by:
                  </dt>
                  <dd>
                   <a href="/user/uid:34820">
                    BMarshall
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:107697">
                    Neon Mama
                   </a>
                   ,
                   <a href="/user/uid:126241">
                    James Kresnik
                   </a>
                  </dd>
                 </dl>
                </div>
                <div class="ct">
                 <p>
                  Years ago, I lived in a state where the chief occupation of each administration seemed to be putting the previous administration in jail. I had just moved there and didn't know too much about the real issues, so it just seemed like a bunch of corrupt people wasting money playing gotcha games.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  That said ... I totally agree with Biden, and I disagree with Sunstein (and totally agree with my post up above, lol). So this is my difference with what you said.
                 </p>
                 <blockquote>
                  <p>
                   Any action against the current administration needs to be seen as fair and non-partisan as possible.
                  </p>
                 </blockquote>
                 <blockquote>
                  <p>
                   Any action against the current administration needs
                   <strong>
                    be
                   </strong>
                   fair and non-partisan.
                  </p>
                 </blockquote>
                 <blockquote>
                  <p>
                   If Bush's people are prosecuted in a manner that can be portrayed as a political move on the part of Democrats ...
                  </p>
                 </blockquote>
                 <blockquote>
                  <p>
                   If Bush's people are prosecuted in a manner that can be portrayed
                   <strong>
                    credibly
                   </strong>
                   as
                   <strong>
                    just
                   </strong>
                   a political move ...
                  </p>
                 </blockquote>
                 <p>
                  So, we can take Sunstein's warning seriously, and I think we should. But we don't let it stop us, but rather make us remember:
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  <strong>
                   Do the right thing.
                   <br/>
                   Do it the right way.
                   <br/>
                   Don't worry that the other party will allege all kinds of nasty things ...
                   <br/>
                   Just make sure they're not true, and that there isn't any evidence that would give those allegations credibility.
                  </strong>
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  It's called spine. It's also called being brave. Because if we don't follow the rule of law, we will not be the land of the free.
                 </p>
                </div>
                <div class="cf">
                 <p class="sig">
                  <i>

           <li id="c158">
            <div class="cx" id="cx22077239">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               Not quite how I read it...
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/584551/22077239#c158?mode=alone;showrate=1#c158">
                6+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:40155">
                 Clzwld
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:44482">
                 vcmvo2

                 keikekaze
                </a>

                </a>

                <a href="/user/uid:152071">
                 allep10
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:159989">
                 fedupcitizen
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               The quote was
              </p>
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                Democrats should avoid replicating retributive efforts
               </p>
              </blockquote>
              <p>
               I took that to mean the kind of witch hunt that took place under Starr.
              </p>
              <p>
               Biden's point is that if criminality can be proven, it should be dealt with. Obama has talked about using the format of the African "Truth Commissions". The point is not
               <strong>
                so
               </strong>
               much the actual punishment as it is the documenting of what was done.
              </p>
              <p>
               That said, Biden's framing is
               <strong>
                perfect
               </strong>
               . It resonates with voters. Only those in power would be against the idea that "no-one is above the law".
              </p>
              <p>
               Another great example of Biden's grasp of what gets through to voters, not pundits.
              </p>
             </div>

             <li id="c260">
              <div class="cx" id="cx22080302">
               <h5>
                <a class="de">
                </a>
                <span class="cu">
                 Sunstein didn't speal about legalities.
                </span>
                <span class="crd ntb">
                 (
                 <a href="/comments/584551/22080302#c260?mode=alone;showrate=1#c260">
                  5+ / 0-
                 </a>
                 )
                </span>
               </h5>
               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:27118">
                   wonmug
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:40155">
                   Clzwld
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:109379">
                   kafkananda
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:120863">
                   daddy4mak
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:126241">
                   James Kresnik
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 He said that maybe there would ensue a 'cycle of criminalizing public service'.
                </p>
                <p>
                 But then again, maybe not.
                </p>
                <p>
                 I too could pontificate on such maybes from the safety of my armchair, though my degree is in Economics. His legal erudition doesn't add any weight to this kind of speculation. My guess is as good as his.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Sunstein's take on the potential 'risk' is a pragmatic one: he has the interests of
                 <em>
                  the Party
                 </em>
                 in mind. It's not an ethical or legal position, and does not address moral imperatives like 'justice' or 'the dignity of the Office', or even 'the will of the people'.
                </p>
                <p>
                 I would hope that Obama, if elected, would rise above Party interests, and decide that the 'risk' was worth it. I would hope that he'd then appoint a special prosecutor or independent counsel to look for evidence of possible criminal misconduct in the Executive Branch -- which the EB in the person of Obama would be entitled to do. (As would Congress, I believe). I would further hope that if such evidence was found, the DOJ would run with that ball and prosecute.
                </p>
                <p>
                 Hope I got the legalities right. As I said, my degree is in Economics.
                </p>

           <li id="c372">
            <div class="cx" id="cx22087596">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               It's common to send mixed messages . . .
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/584551/22087596#c372?mode=alone;showrate=1#c372">
                1+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:27118">
                 wonmug
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               It's a way to let your enemies know that actions have consequences without making the threat your defining feature. In fact, what will happen to the Bush regime if Obama is elected can't be known now, and it won't be. They are waiting to see what resources they have. If the election goes as well as the last, you can be sure that there will be an investigation, at least. When Biden says "If there is a basis . . ." he isn't just referring to the facts of what happened but the political possibility of doing anything about it.
              </p>
             </div>

              </span>

              </p>

              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                Perhaps
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/584551/22077551#c172?mode=alone;showrate=1#c172">
                 1+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:53243">
                  amRadioHed
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                because they feel more confident they're going to win.
               </p>
               <p>
                You don't say you're going to go after the previous administration unless you're pretty sure you're going to be taking over.
               </p>
               <p>
                Even so, they wouldn't want to make it too confrontational - they don't want people to think they're just going to be out for revenge.
               </p>
               <p>
                Justice - that's another thing entirely.
               </p>

             The statement was very well measured and worded
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">

             <a href="/comments/584551/22076192#c80?mode=alone;showrate=1#c80">

              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:130185">
               caps lock on
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:140506">
               rsmpdx
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:146015">
               Rabbithead
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:153053">
               Losty
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:154397">
               strangedemocracy
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:159989">
               fedupcitizen
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             to be consistent with the campaign theme on top of it all, which I think is just excellent; when I have heard Obama discuss this in the past, he has been similarly focused most primarily on not suggesting any hint of pre-existing bias or predetermined conclusion, and while many here thought that he was way too tamed and restrained in doing so,
             <strong>
              the fact is that it gives any future criminal charges that are filed no legitimate political rebuttal
             </strong>
             . It's the same Constitutional principle that our justice system follows in calling someone a "suspect" or an "alleged" killer even if the murder was witnessed by millions on television; not only does does this tenet protect the innocent,
             <strong>
              but it also gives credibility to prosecuting the guilty once they are convicted
             </strong>
             .
            </p>
           </div>

         <li id="c141">

           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             Obama has been saying this for at least
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/584551/22077002#c141?mode=alone;showrate=1#c141">
              8+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:112">
               Devin
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:20449">
               mmacdDE
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:36086">
               hazzcon
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:93051">
               moosely2006
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:112208">
               ShadowSD
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:139736">
               Fonsia
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:152306">
               IngeniousGirl
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:159989">
               fedupcitizen
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             over a year. I asked him about this very subject at YearlyKos in 2007 and he stated the very same thing--that one of the first things he would do would be to direct his AG to go through every Executive Order, through every signing statement, etc., and determine whether or not crimes had been committed. If found, his administrators would bring the perpetrators to justice. No one is above the law.
            </p>
            <p>
             I've heard him state the same thing at subsequent Town Halls as he has campaigned, as well. The fact that people here have not acknowledged this fact does not mean Obama has not been saying this for a long time now. Biden is just saying what Obama has been saying all along. But many folks at DailyKos didn't really get on the Obama bandwagon until Edwards dropped out, so there was a lot of misinformation and non-information perpetrated here for a long time.
            </p>
           </div>

            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Because Obama's language was reasonable and
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/584551/22077538#c169?mode=alone;showrate=1#c169">
               4+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="crs">
             <dl>
              <dt>
               Recommended by:
              </dt>
              <dd>
               <a href="/user/uid:65834">
                Jennifer Clare
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:93051">
                moosely2006
               </a>
               ,
               <a href="/user/uid:159989">
                fedupcitizen
               </a>

            </div>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              measured, he therefore was not being passionate enough for some people here, so a lot of folks just didn't notice it.
             </p>
             <p>
              This phenomenon is still going on in this diary:
             </p>
             <blockquote>
              <p>
               Update #2: As pointed out in the comments, Obama himself
               <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/04/15/obama-would-immediately-r_n_96690.html">
                has said something similar
               </a>
               recently. I must have missed that when it first appeared.
               <strong>
                But I would like to point out that Biden's statement is much more aggressive than Obama's, and that in itself is noteworthy.
               </strong>
              </p>
             </blockquote>
             <p>
              The only thing about Obama's statement in the linked article linked that was different from Biden's statement is where it says: "He worried that such a probe could be spun as 'a partisan witch hunt.'" That's not being less aggressive than Biden; it's a fact that a probe will be spun as exactly that by the GOP, and that is why both Obama AND his runningmate are making efforts in their statements not to even hint at any predetermined conclusions.
             </p>
             <p>
              Excellent post, I wish I could rec it a thousand times.
             </p>

            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:93051">
               moosely2006
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             ...to God and only a few of our ears.
            </p>
            <p>
             Nothing can do more to restore America's credibility and standing in the world than investigation and prosecution of Bush Administration war crimes and torture. The investigations and prosecutions of course need to extend more broadly, and address corruption and mismanagement across the board - Department of the Interior, Department of Justice, EPA, even DHHS.
            </p>
            <p>
             But I would prefer if Obama and Biden don't make too big of a media event out of this right now. There's two reasons for this. First, many independents and low information voters have more or less a Gerald Ford approach to things - let's not air the dirty laundry in public, and let's not prosecute. They may be wrong, but prosecutions may do more for the base than for the wider public. Obama's OK with his base, and he doesn't need to say much about this now for political purposes. (He does need to act on it if elected). Second, the Republicans are still able to destroy evidence and obstruct justice. They will do so, of course, but there's no need to make the election about prosecuting Bush Administration officials or the scale of the destruction of public records will simply increase.
            </p>
            <p>
             Get elected, quietly put together an investigation strategy during the transition phase, and then go after them. But I'm glad it's a little quiet right now.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             God, who gave man scabies, also gave him hands to scratch them.
            </p>

           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             From your keyboard....
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/584551/22081386#c287?mode=alone;showrate=1#c287">
              1+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:27118">
               wonmug
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             ... and Joe's lips... to the monitor and ears of the Goddess.
            </p>
            <p>
             Or the Flying Spaghetti Monster.
            </p>
            <p>
             Or
             <em>
              someone
             </em>
             ...!
            </p>
            <p>
             Okay. On a serious note,
             <em>
              I'll believe it when I see it
             </em>
             , but this is the FIRST time I've seen a potentially solid reason to vote the Obama-Biden ticket; if they
             <em>
              started
             </em>
             this process BEFORE election day I'd be even more impressed. I like Joe 'cuz he's an attack dog and we need that. I'm probably only one of a very small group of people who appreciates his forthright ability to speak his mind, but I sincerely can't express how much I like that about him.
            </p>
            <p>
             From the first lie about Iraq and WMD (I believed Hans Blix all along, you see, and it's only been proved he told the truth), I was in favor of impeaching Georgie and Dickie... so all along my #1 "issue" has always been impeachment and it was the first thing I checked on when I was trying to decide to back for prez. Dennis Kucinich is the only one who favored impeachment AND
             <em>
              actually did something about it
             </em>
             - and, BTW, Kucinich's
             <em>
              not-for-profit
             </em>
             healthcare plan is still the best I've seen, too. In '06 Conyers drew up impeachment papers before the election, rooked a lot of people into voting Dem because of that, and then Conyers did nothing whatsoever about filing the papers or pursuing impeachment and adopted Pelosi's stance.
            </p>
            <p>
             Still, since this is before election day, lots of things we want to hear can be said, implied like it's gonna happen (like Conyers did), they can change their minds after election day. I've always been afraid all along that after being elected they'd be more interested in singing
             <em>
              Kumbaya
             </em>
             and "letting bygones be bygones in the interests of moving forward."
            </p>
            <p>
             So, I'll believe it when I see it... but it does sound good only because I've wished for this for so many years.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             (`*._(`*._(-IMPEACH-)_.*)_.*)
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:84130">
              NonnyO
             </a>

            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">

             <a href="/comments/584551/22082778#c319?mode=alone;showrate=1#c319">
              0+ / 0-

           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             As a younger adult, i never would have imagined that Ronald Wilson Reagan would have been revered as the anti FDR God, but there he is, hanging over little Georgie's bed in a gilded frame.
             <br/>
             I don't want to be closer to a cardiac when BookTV interviews some author of the NYT's best seller: "Bush 43, the Real People's President" subtitled: "Saving the Nation after 9/11".

         <ul class="cm i1" id="k22084079">
          <li id="c386">
           <div class="cx" id="cx22090919">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              It's Been on MY Mind for Eight Years
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/584551/22090919#c386?mode=alone;showrate=1#c386">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              What happened to me when I was living in Austin, Texas while Bush was governor has been on MY mind for eight years. But I was born and raised in Delaware so I did start to feel a little better about it after I wrote Joe Biden a letter in mid-2005. At that time, I asked him specifically, "Senator Biden, what has happened to my country"? His answer came on "Meet The Press" in November 2006, when he said, "We can't get RID of the president". But that was THEN and this is NOW and Joe Biden is going to be our next VP!
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:174243">
               Centrocitta
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/584551/22090919#c386">

         <li id="c365">
          <div class="cx" id="cx22086541">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             And this wasn't the first time
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/584551/22086541#c365?mode=alone;showrate=1#c365">
              1+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:107697">
               Neon Mama
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             Not to brag (ok, so it's bragging!), but I pointed this out right after Obama picked Biden. Lots of people were saying it wasn't that great a choice, and that Obama could have done better. While I (partly) agreed, I also remembered something that Biden had said last year.
            </p>
            <p>
             From my
             <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/story/2008/8/23/13022/6504/277/573313">
              diary
             </a>
             about 10 days ago:
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              From August of last year, in an interview with Newsweek:
             </p>
             <p>
              Question: You once called Slobodan Milosevic a war criminal to his face. You also told Dick Cheney that, were he not a constitutional officer, the president should fire him. So when it comes to the mistakes made in Iraq, why should impeachment of President Bush be off the table?
             </p>
             <p>
              Biden: It shouldnt be. But impeachment like everything else is a matter of priorities and responsibility. In order to move on impeachment now, we would be put in a position at a very, very delicate time in our nations history, of having necessarily to take our eye off the ball on a host of other things that will have longer-lasting impact on the security of this country. As a practical matter, it sucks all the oxygen out of the air. We would effectively be paralyzed for the next six months or longer. The alternative, and its taken me time to think through, I think we should be acquiring and accumulating all the data that is appropriate for possibly bringing criminal charges against members of this administration at a later date.
             </p>
            </blockquote>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             "Any dictator would admire the uniformity and obedience of the U.S. media." -- Noam Chomsky
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:156135">
              ratmach
             </a>

             <a href="/comments/584551/22086541#c365">

            </p>

             <a href="#c1">

            </p>
           </div>

           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             I just watched Bidens Sarasota town hall (it just ended at 6:00 pm Wednesday)and I need a Utube or recording of the event but dont have a clue how to get it.It was streamed live on CNN and Im telling you Joe was amazing,and I dont use that word often.His fuckin passion and on the surface patriotism was moving to say the least.The idea that we would want to muzzle him is beyond stupidity.A lady who is a supporter said her rich friends are worried about his taxing people making over 250 Gs a year.What should I tell them? Its time to show patriotism ! He brought the house down.This was the least of it too.Unfuckingbelievable is what it was!If someone could post it here,or e-mail it to playthetri@aol.com............the Q&amp;A is all I need to show my wife,or just tell me how to find it myself,Id appreciate it.Yall may want to see it yourself,it'll make you proud.  Greg

         <li id="c166">
          <div class="cx" id="cx22077497">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             is that a shredder I hear?
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/584551/22077497#c166?mode=alone;showrate=1#c166">
              2+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:53243">
               amRadioHed
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:75333">
               joe shikspack
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             And hard drives being erased are much quieter than shredders, but preparations are long underway by the Cheneyites to expunge records of all kinds. Pursuit of legal satisfaction will be severely hampered by missing records and massive collective amnesia. It will be a real test of the administration's prosecutorial powers to come up with solid cases.
            </p>
            <p>
             Not sayin' it can't be done, but someone's going to need both big shovels and fine toothed combs to nail actionable criminal activity, despite that so much of it has been done in plain sight. Sickening to think of what's gone on out of sight.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">
            <p class="sig">
             Fear is the mind killer - Frank Herbert, Dune
            </p>
            <p class="cb">
             by
             <a href="/user/uid:159850">
              p gorden lippy
             </a>
             on
             <a href="/comments/584551/22077497#c166">
              Wed Sep 03, 2008 at 09:08:43 AM PDT
             </a>
            </p>
            <p class="cl">
             [
             <a href="#c3">
              Parent
             </a>
             ]
            </p>
           </div>
          </div>

        <li id="c4">
         <div class="cx" id="cx22075415">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Not Really A Shocker
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/584551/22075415#c4?mode=alone;showrate=1#c4">
             7+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">

           <ul class="cm i1" id="k22076080">
            <li id="c161">
             <div class="cx" id="cx22077330">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                He has said he will look into it ...
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/584551/22077330#c161?mode=alone;showrate=1#c161">
                 2+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="crs">
               <dl>
                <dt>
                 Recommended by:
                </dt>
                <dd>
                 <a href="/user/uid:44591">
                  joanneleon
                 </a>
                 ,
                 <a href="/user/uid:139417">
                  SuburbanGrrrl
                 </a>
                </dd>
               </dl>
              </div>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                ... the question is what that means. I expect very little help from Congress in pursuing matters, because they have not done so this entire 2 year term, and there is certainly enough smoke to investigate a fire. I think the Congressional Dems are afraid that investigating would reveal their own complicity, which is significant.
               </p>
               <p>
                Now what we DO have for data is Obama's own vote on the FISA law, which was a clear political move. Obama recorded an ad supporting the shameful John Barrow in Georgia, who is one of the blue dog "Republican in sheep's clothing" Democrats who cheered on the war votes and the civil liberties stripping. Obama is playing nice with the party on these things, to his detriment, though certainly understandable. Since we are on his side on a lot of other things, he basically decided to not give the right anything to attack him with. As politics, I understand -- as constitutional law, I was terribly disappointed.
               </p>
               <p>
                On the bright side, Obama voted for ALL of the amendments to the FISA law that would have helped with some of the "oversight" things, but all of the amendments got struck down -- basically the Democrats voluntarily gave the President virtually the exact bill he wanted, any words by Susstein or anyone that this was a material improvement on the Senate version is silly.
               </p>
               <p>
                Put simply, I think Obama will think about investigating the crimes, but I don't think there will be enough traction from the Democratic "protect the beltwat status quo" congress for it to lead anywhere exciting.
               </p>
              </div>

               According to wikipedia, Ford pardoned Nixon prior to any legal action having been taken against him.
              </p>
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                A presidential pardon may be granted at any time, however, and as when Ford pardoned Nixon, the pardoned person need not yet have been convicted or even formally charged with a crime.
               </p>
              </blockquote>
              <p>
               There don't seem to be many limits at all on the presidential pardon. The language of the Constitution states, and this is again from Wikipedia:
              </p>
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                In the United States, the pardon power for Federal crimes is granted to the President by the United States Constitution, Article II, Section 2, which states that the President:
                <em>
                 <strong>
                  "shall have power to grant reprieves and pardons for offenses against the United States, except in cases of impeachment."
                 </strong>
                </em>
               </p>
              </blockquote>
              <p>
               From what I can see, these powers have been interpreted very broadly by the Supreme Court in the past. This is not what I'd like, but it seems to be the case.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:120146">
                LearningCurve
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/584551/22076018#c54">
                Wed Sep 03, 2008 at 08:28:23 AM PDT
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c22">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k22076018">

        <li id="c13">
         <div class="cx" id="cx22075540">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">

          <li id="c77">
           <div class="cx" id="cx22076177">
            <h5>
             <a class="de">
             </a>
             <span class="cu">
              Wow, I didn't know that
             </span>
             <span class="crd ntb">
              (
              <a href="/comments/584551/22076177#c77?mode=alone;showrate=1#c77">
               0+ / 0-
              </a>
              )
             </span>
            </h5>
            <div class="ct">
             <p>
              I was just saying that I never heard a definitive statement from Obama on this subject.
             </p>
             <p>
              Do you happen to know where I could find a quote?
             </p>
            </div>
            <div class="cf">
             <p class="sig">
              <i>
               "The true measure of a man is how he treats someone who can do him absolutely no good."
--Samuel Johnson
              </i>
             </p>
             <p class="cb">
              by
              <a href="/user/uid:44591">
               joanneleon
              </a>
              on
              <a href="/comments/584551/22076177#c77">
               Wed Sep 03, 2008 at 08:33:31 AM PDT
              </a>
             </p>
             <p class="cl">

             </p>
            </div>
           </div>
          </li>
          <ul class="cm i1" id="k22076177">
           <li id="c120">
            <div class="cx" id="cx22076675">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               What Obama has said so far,
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/584551/22076675#c120?mode=alone;showrate=1#c120">
                4+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:41961">
                 rmx2630
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:44591">
                 joanneleon
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:75333">
                 joe shikspack
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:168006">
                 jawboneblues
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2008/4/14/222339/071/485/495813">
                courtesy attytood:
               </a>
              </p>
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                What I would want to do is to have my Justice Department and my Attorney General immediately review the information that's already there and to find out are there inquiries that need to be pursued. I can't prejudge that because we don't have access to all the material right now. I think that you are right, if crimes have been committed, they should be investigated. You're also right that I would not want my first term consumed by what was perceived on the part of Republicans as a partisan witch hunt because I think we've got too many problems we've got to solve.
               </p>
               <p>
                So this is an area where I would want to exercise judgment -- I would want to find out directly from my Attorney General -- having pursued, having looked at what's out there right now -- are there possibilities of genuine crimes as opposed to really bad policies. And I think it's important-- one of the things we've got to figure out in our political culture generally is distinguishing betyween really dumb policies and policies that rise to the level of criminal activity. You know, I often get questions about impeachment at town hall meetings and I've said that is not something I think would be fruitful to pursue because I think that impeachment is something that should be reserved for exceptional circumstances. Now,
                <strong>
                 if I found out that there were high officials who knowingly, consciously broke existing laws, engaged in coverups of those crimes with knowledge forefront,
                </strong>
                then I think a basic principle of our Constitution is nobody above the law -- and I think that's roughly how I would look at it.
               </p>
              </blockquote>
              <p>
               (Emphasis mine.) Except we already know all of that, and yet Obama is steadfastly against impeachment. I just don't see him making indictments at all. Doubly so when one of his chief legal advisors, Cass Sunstein,
               <a href="http://www.democracynow.org/2008/7/22/obama_adviser_cass_sunstein_debates_glenn">
                says this:
               </a>
              </p>
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                the idea that its an impeachable offense to adopt an incorrect interpretation of the Presidents power, that, I think, is too far-reaching.
               </p>
              </blockquote>
              <p>
               The whole point of impeachment is for when federal officials exceed their allowable power (or exhibit gross negligence).
               <a href="http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2008/6/10/13474/1028">
                Explicit criminality is not a requirement for impeachment.
               </a>
              </p>
              <p>
               And Sunstein is either a fool or a knave to say this:
              </p>
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                For the President to issue a preemptive pardon of all illegality on the part of those involved in his administration would be intolerable, and the political retribution for that should be extreme. I expect the President wont do that.
               </p>
              </blockquote>
              <p>
               There will be no prosecutions, not unless there's a mass movement on the scale of the Civil Rights Movement to make Obama's attorney general do it.
              </p>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">
               Government and laws are the agreement we all make to secure everyone's freedom.
              </p>
              <p class="cb">
               by
               <a href="/user/uid:51603">
                Simplify
               </a>
               on
               <a href="/comments/584551/22076675#c120">
                Wed Sep 03, 2008 at 08:46:52 AM PDT
               </a>
              </p>
              <p class="cl">
               [
               <a href="#c77">
                Parent
               </a>
               ]
              </p>
             </div>
            </div>
           </li>
           <ul class="cm i1" id="k22076675">
            <li id="c189">
             <div class="cx" id="cx22077965">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                feet meet fire...
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/584551/22077965#c189?mode=alone;showrate=1#c189">
                 0+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="ct">
               <blockquote>
                <p>
                 There will be no prosecutions, not unless there's a mass movement on the scale of the Civil Rights Movement to make Obama's attorney general do it.
                </p>
               </blockquote>
               <p>
                that's where we come in...
               </p>
              </div>
              <div class="cf">
               <p class="sig">

               </p>
               <blockquote>
                <p>
                 ...impeachment is something that should be reserved for exceptional circumstances.Now, if I found out that there were high officials who knowingly, consciously broke existing laws, engaged in coverups of those crimes with knowledge forefront,...
                </p>

               <p>
                He hasn't seen exceptional circumstances yet?
