           <li id="c132">
            <div class="cx" id="cx22076823">
             <h5>
              <a class="de">
              </a>
              <span class="cu">
               corrected link
              </span>
              <span class="crd ntb">
               (
               <a href="/comments/584551/22076823#c132?mode=alone;showrate=1#c132">
                0+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               Same story as the Daily Kos post I linked above:
              </p>
              <blockquote>
               <p>
                <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/04/15/obama-would-immediately-r_n_96690.html">
                 Obama Would "Immediately Review" Potential Of Crimes In Bush White House
                </a>
                <br/>
                Attytood  |  April 15, 2008
               </p>
              </blockquote>
             </div>
             <div class="cf">
              <p class="sig">

        <li id="c19">
         <div class="cx" id="cx22075683">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Woot! Go get 'em Joe...and in fairness Congress
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/584551/22075683#c19?mode=alone;showrate=1#c19">
             6+ / 0-

             </a>

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:74131">

             </a>

             <a href="/user/uid:85194">

             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            I think it's been hard, in the context of severe executive recalcitrance, for Congress to fully pursue BushCo's many layers of wrong-doing.
           </p>
           <p>
            The law is a long slow grind, and the Bush has been slow-walking this through the end of his term, and we've only got a few months left. With the Attorney General unwill to serve supoenas, and loyal Bushies still serving in most cases as US Attorneys, it's hard to get things done quickly.
           </p>
           <p>
            One reason we need to win this election is so that we can reimpose the rule of law on the executive. That happens a lot more easily if Obama-Biden win. If McCain's in there, something might happen, but it will be a long, long uphill push.
           </p>
          </div>

            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             And Congresspeople are complicit
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/584551/22077227#c157?mode=alone;showrate=1#c157">
              2+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>

           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:75333">
               joe shikspack
              </a>
              ,
              <a href="/user/uid:168006">
               jawboneblues
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              <a href="http://emptywheel.firedoglake.com/2008/09/01/is-this-why-congress-folded-on-fisa/">
               In other words, this
              </a>
              was the meeting at which at least five members of Congress--at least one Democrat--agreed that the Administration should continue illegally wiretapping American citizens even after DOJ's own lawyers warned against doing so. There are disputes about what went on in that meeting. And Alberto Gonzales, sometime after he became Attorney General in 2005, repeatedly took his notes of that meeting out of his safe at DOJ and wandered around DC with them in his briefcase. No word where he went with that briefcase or whom he spoke to.
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             Plus, Congress has been unconstitutionally handing its proper powers and responsibilities to the President for a long time now. How many people choose to vote for a Congressional candidate based upon whether that candidate will reclaim legislative power? It would take the public and press demanding that Congresspeople do so for any of this to change. It's a fundamental flaw in the Constitution  Congress was supposed to selfishly guard its power, but instead Congresspeople hoard individual power (committee chairs etc.) while giving away institutional power so they won't be held responsible for anything.
            </p>
           </div>
           <div class="cf">

             <a href="/user/uid:10803">
              cotterperson
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:19716">
              TracieLynn
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:54433">
              boofdah
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:88322">
              pradeep
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            there will be a LOUD media drum to the tone of "put it all behind us" come January 21st. They don't want the Bush gang brought to account and they will label anyone who doesn't simply forget that Bush ever existed a vengeful mean-spirited extremist bent on reliving the past.
           </p>
           <p>
            If an Obama administration ends up pursuing the multitude of criminal acts perpetrated by the Bush gang and nothing else... it will be worth it!
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">

        <ul class="cm i1" id="k22076283">
         <li id="c264">
          <div class="cx" id="cx22080341">
           <h5>
            <a class="de">
            </a>
            <span class="cu">
             I prefer my campaign promises...
            </span>
            <span class="crd ntb">
             (
             <a href="/comments/584551/22080341#c264?mode=alone;showrate=1#c264">
              1+ / 0-
             </a>
             )
            </span>
           </h5>
           <div class="crs">
            <dl>
             <dt>
              Recommended by:
             </dt>
             <dd>
              <a href="/user/uid:36351">
               The Walrus
              </a>
             </dd>
            </dl>
           </div>
           <div class="ct">
            <p>
             ... to be somewhere in the realm of plausibility.
            </p>
            <p>
             The idea that Obama will lift one finger to punish Bush-era crimes doesn't pass the laugh test.
            </p>

            <li id="c272">
             <div class="cx" id="cx22080831">
              <h5>
               <a class="de">
               </a>
               <span class="cu">
                I don't understand...
               </span>
               <span class="crd ntb">
                (
                <a href="/comments/584551/22080831#c272?mode=alone;showrate=1#c272">
                 0+ / 0-
                </a>
                )
               </span>
              </h5>
              <div class="ct">
               <p>
                Those guards at Abu Ghraib were not that smart. If I were them, and I were asked to do things like what they were asked to do (putting aside the immorality of it for a second), the next thing I'd have told my commander is:
               </p>
               <p>
                "I want direct and precise orders
                <strong>
                 on paper
                </strong>
                of what
                <strong>
                 exactly
                </strong>
                you want me to do. At the bottom of those orders, I want
                <strong>
                 your
                </strong>
                signature."
               </p>
               <p>
                I don't know much about military procedures, but it seems like a no-brainer to make a request like that when you are "ordered" to do questionable activities like Abu Ghraib-type stuff. Then at least you have documentation that you were in fact ordered to do the things you did.
               </p>
              </div>

               <p class="sig">

                <a class="de">

                <span class="cu">
                 military
                </span>

                 <a href="/comments/584551/22081561#c292?mode=alone;showrate=1#c292">
                  2+ / 0-
                 </a>

               <div class="crs">
                <dl>
                 <dt>
                  Recommended by:
                 </dt>
                 <dd>
                  <a href="/user/uid:4449">
                   Sparhawk
                  </a>
                  ,
                  <a href="/user/uid:5137">
                   glitterscale
                  </a>
                 </dd>
                </dl>
               </div>
               <div class="ct">
                <p>
                 The military doesn't work that way. When an officer tells you to jump, you jump. Failure to do so can result in unpleasantness.
                </p>
                <p>
                 I don't believe anyone actually ordered the privates at Abu Ghraib to abuse the detainees. I do believe someone at the direction of an officer (probably colonel or above) began the abuse. The less-than-bright lower enlisted personnel followed suit, not realizing the trouble they were causing themselves. I remember hearing quotes from Lynndie England to the effect, "It seemed liked fun. Everyone was doing it." Upper levels of the chain of command were protected and lower ranking enlisted were convicted.
                </p>

        <li id="c114">
         <div class="cx" id="cx22076587">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            This is a mistake
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/584551/22076587#c114?mode=alone;showrate=1#c114">
             5+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:18836">
              tyler93023
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:18994">
              JohnInWestland
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:21243">
              C Mac
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:51603">
              Simplify
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:168846">
              Black Leather Rain
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            From my many years as an academic, one learns that you NEVER let anyone know that you intend to knife them until you are slipping the shiv into a mortal target. Up to now, the Dems had been doing an excellent job of putting their enemies at ease by their inability to fight.
           </p>
           <p>
            If this is a real goal of Obama and Biden, Biden and everyone else should STFU until the indictments are filed. The Bushies are probably guilty of crimes that carry the death penalty and if the Bu$h crime syndicate members think they may actually be held accountable for those crimes, they will do ANYTHING to prevent an accounting. And we know that they won't stop at mass murder.
           </p>
           <p>
            This was a big mistake, unless of course there really is no intent to carry out a campaign of justice. The recent history of the Democrats suggests this is simply talk and not indicative of any intent to actually do something. I think the part of the statement "If there has been a basis upon which you can pursue someone for a criminal violation," is a dog whistle for "we're not really serious".
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">
           </p>

             <span class="cu">

             </span>

           </p>
           <p>
            After our dinner and his speech, everyone who had the stamina to wade into the crowd had an opportunity to speak with him for a second or two on his way out of the room. I asked him, hypothetically, if he were to run for president in '08 - he smiled and brushed off the idea- and were he to win, would he pursue any criminal charges against the former administration. He told me that if he found cause for criminal charges, he would pursue them "with every fiber of my being". So. I guess Obama/Biden are on the same page.
           </p>

            Bush violated the AUMF
           </span>

           <p>
            My source for that claim? Joe Biden, who said it on television not long ago.
           </p>
           <p>
            Bush violated the AUMF when he took America to war in Iraq. Bush's fraudulent declaration to Congress and subsequent invasion of Iraq violated the AUMF, the UN Charter, the War Powers Act, and was a flagrant, unconstitutional and treasonous usurption of power.
           </p>
           <p>
            The decision to invade Iraq completes a set of charges that constitute The Crime Against Peace, the war crime for which the Nazi High Command was HANGED.
           </p>
           <p>
            Cheney's "Energy Task Force" decided, ahead of time (March 2001), which Iraqi oilfields would be divided by the oil companies in attendance. This is evidence that the Bush Administration, like the Nazis, premeditated invading and occupying Iraq to loot that country.
           </p>
           <p>
            We'll look around and see if evidence of any crimes exists?
           </p>
           <p>
            We've got at least 35 of them for death penalty crimes. Hundreds more for life-in-prison. Possibly thousands more for at least a decade in jail
            <em>
             and game over on any positions of power for the rest of their lives.
            </em>
           </p>
           <p>
            And when I say "positions of power," I don't restrict that to government office. These fascists should never be allowed to sit on a board, be an executive, a consultant, a teacher, a professor, or even a church board member. NO AUTHORITY, EVER, OF ANY KIND. They should have all property and cash and stocks FORFEIT as well.
           </p>
           <p>
            There are janitor jobs and fruit to be picked.
           </p>

             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:40726">
              SadieB
             </a>
             ,
             <a href="/user/uid:131796">
              In her own Voice
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            who think that impeachment is the only way and why we need to lay off Pelosi!!!! Bush cannot escape being held accountable for his crimes by leaving office!!!!
            <br/>
            How do I know this? Because Joe Biden was at a book signing, aired by C-SPAN, for Elizabeth de la Vegas book,
            <em>
             U.S. V. BUSH
            </em>
            , in which she, a former federal prosecutor, makes the case for the indictment of the five top Bush administrators, beginning AT THE TOP for felony fraud...charges that Bush cannot innoculate himself from by some forward-active pardon and for which, not being in office anymore, is a defense. She says, that crimes committed by persons in office are not washed from the slate when that person leaves office...the crimes follow the perpetrator!
            <br/>
            Joe was not at that signing because de la Vega was a nutcake or that he didn't have anything else to do! We got to trust in the system.
           </p>
          </div>
          <div class="cf">
           <p class="sig">

            I mean if the Bushies and their secret backers really believe this, what won't they stop at to make sure that Obama/Biden don't win? Yeah, I know, it sounds like tin foil talking, but when I read certain diaries here, like the ones about the Anthrax letters, it makes me wonder. (Well that and watching too many Jason Bourne movies.)
           </p>

          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Note to Secret Service and Right-Wing Trolls:
           </p>
           <p>
            This is the title of a song that I like. It is one of my favorites.
           </p>
           <p>
            It is also the title of a Clint Eastwood Movie, so that makes it okay.
           </p>
           <p>
            Just so's you know.
           </p>
           <p>
            It also happens to be the fate of Saddam Hussein. You remember him, right?
           </p>

             1+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="crs">
           <dl>
            <dt>
             Recommended by:
            </dt>
            <dd>
             <a href="/user/uid:40726">
              SadieB
             </a>
            </dd>
           </dl>
          </div>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            Obama/Biden that is. They could force this into the first paragraph. The election needs to be a referendum on Bush. If the conversation gets too dense and confused over identity politics as the GOP plans, they may have to tap into the anger more directly.
           </p>
           <p>
            It's a deep well if they want to go there. Not the safest route but the way things are going, it may become necessary.
           </p>
           <p>
            I would love to win this election that way. Not just a full throated rejection of Bush failures as Obama has been doing. But a full throated denunciation of Bush crimes.
           </p>
          </div>

          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            and if they do it, I will consider re-joining the Democratic Party. But after watching the waffling of Pelosi &amp; Co. for so long now, I'm not holding my breath. These people (Democrats in Congress) have been enablers for this criminality even as recently as a few months ago. I don't expect any real change unless Obama &amp; Biden make it so. Please make it so!
           </p>

               <a href="/comments/584551/22125731#c462?mode=alone;showrate=1#c462">
                2+ / 0-
               </a>
               )
              </span>
             </h5>
             <div class="crs">
              <dl>
               <dt>
                Recommended by:
               </dt>
               <dd>
                <a href="/user/uid:146449">
                 DiedInSuburbia
                </a>
                ,
                <a href="/user/uid:156135">
                 ratmach
                </a>
               </dd>
              </dl>
             </div>
             <div class="ct">
              <p>
               That's how I'd describe Bush. Is there anything lower than that?
              </p>
             </div>

        <li id="c447">
         <div class="cx" id="cx22114963">
          <h5>
           <a class="de">
           </a>
           <span class="cu">
            Why did the Bushies reject the ICC so loudly?
           </span>
           <span class="crd ntb">
            (
            <a href="/comments/584551/22114963#c447?mode=alone;showrate=1#c447">
             0+ / 0-
            </a>
            )
           </span>
          </h5>
          <div class="ct">
           <p>
            They were against the establishment of an International Criminal Court because they worried they may be sent there if anyone found out about the torture. A holiday in The Hague.
           </p>
           <p>
            But since we never signed that treaty, we must deliver justice on our own soil for anyone who started an unnecessary war. That is the very definition of a "crime against humanity."
           </p>
          </div>

           <p class="sig">

  <script type="text/javascript">
   $(document).ready( App.initOnReady );
	
        kos.story_id = 584551;
        kos.sid = '2008/9/3/11624/73765';
		//kos.LAST_SEEN = '0';
		kos.LAST_SEEN = DailyKos.CommentCount.getReadCommentCount(kos.story_id);
		kos.pub_status = 'published';
		kos.version = 0;
		kos.trcount = 0;
		kos.trremain = 0;
		kos.serial = 485;
		kos.updated = '2015-06-22 15:57:27';
		kos.hidingchoice = false;
		kos.can_comment = 0;

		jQuery(function() {
			jQuery('li.from-mobile .cx').each(function() {
				var counts				= jQuery(this).find('.crd.ntb').clone(true),
						dropTriangle 	= jQuery(this).find('.de').clone(true);

				jQuery(this).find('h5').hide();
				jQuery(this).find('.ct').prepend(dropTriangle);
				jQuery(this).find('.ct').prepend(counts);
				jQuery(this).find('.ct::first-line').css('background', 'red')	});
		});

  <script type="text/javascript">
   DailyKos.Metrics.metricsOn = (0 === 1);
	  DailyKos.Metrics.sampleSize = 20;
		DailyKos.Metrics.setUserProperties({
			requestFormat: 'full site',
			subscriber: false,
			mobile: $.browser.mobile,
			loggedIn: false,
			staff: false
		});
		DailyKos.Metrics.init();
  </script>
  <script type="text/javascript">
   if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/story/)) {
			  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Story', {  url: "http://www.dailykos.com/story/2008/09/03/584551/-Biden-Criminal-charges-against-Bush-Admin-on-the-table", 
			                                            blog: "Devin",
			                                            author: $('.author').children('a').first().html(),
			                                            title: $('#titleHref').html()
			                                          });
			} else if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/comment/)) {
			  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Comment');
			}
  </script>
  <script type="text/javascript">
   if($.cookie('meter_user') !== 'false') {
		if ($('#ePostButton').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('#ePostButton').click(function() { 
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Posted Comment', { 
		      repliedTo: $(this).parents('#eP').prevAll('.cb').children('a').first().html() 
		    });
		  });
		}
		
		if (!!document.location.pathname.match('activate') &amp;&amp; $('h1:contains("Welcome to Daily Kos!")').length &gt; 0) {
		  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Signed Up');
		}
		
		if (document.location.pathname === '/') {
		  if (document.location.hostname.match(/^www|^dailykos/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Front Page');
		  } else {
		    var subdomain = document.location.hostname.split('.')[0];
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Vertical', { name: subdomain });
		  }
		}
		
		if ($('.ratinate').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('.ratinate').click(function() { DailyKos.Metrics.track('Recommended Comment') });
		}
		
		if ($('.do-addRating.type-story').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('.do-addRating.type-story').click(function() { DailyKos.Metrics.track('Recommended Story') });
		}
		
		if ($("form[action$='publishHow']").length &gt; 0) {
		  $(document).ready(function() {
			  $('.type-story.do-publishHow').click(function() { DailyKos.Metrics.track('Published Story') });
			 });
		}
		
		if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/user/) &amp;&amp; $('li.here').length &gt; 0) {
		  if ($('.pageMenu:first li.here').children('a').html().match(/Stream/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Stream', { name: $('.name').children('a').html() });
		  } else if ($('.pageMenu:first li.here').children('a').html().match(/Profile/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Profile', { name: $('.name').children('a').html() });
		  } else if ($('.pageMenu:last li.here').children('a').html().match(/My Recent Replies/)) {
		    DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Replies');
		  }
		} 
		
		if ($('#search-tabbed').length &gt; 0) {
		  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Searched');
		}
		
		if ($('#group-tables').length &gt; 0) {
			DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Groups List');
		}
		
		if (document.location.pathname.match(/^\/groups/) &amp;&amp; $("#group_info").length &gt; 0) {
		  DailyKos.Metrics.track('Viewed Group', { name: $('.name').children('a').text() });
		}
		
		if ($('.do-hotlist.type-user, .do-unHotlist.type-user').length &gt; 0) {
		  $('.do-hotlist.type-user, .do-unHotlist.type-user').click(function() {
		    var nickName;
		    nickName = ($(this).prev('a').html() || $('.name a').html())
		    if ($(this).hasClass('do-hotlist')) {
		      DailyKos.Metrics.track('Followed User', { nickname: nickName }) 
		    } else if ($(this).hasClass('do-unHotlist')) {
		      DailyKos.Metrics.track('Unfollowed User', { nickname: nickName }) 
		    }    
		  });
		}
	}
  </script>
